article.headline: Utah 75, Colorado State 52
article.story: FORT COLLINS, Colo. (AP) -- After struggling early against Colorado State's three 7-footers, Andrew Bogut figured out what he needed to do: slow down. Using his quickness to get around Colorado State's towering front line, Bogut scored 10 of his 25 points during Utah's 25-3 second-half run and grabbed career-high 18 rebounds to help the Utes beat Colorado State 75-52 Monday night for their 10th straight victory. "I was rushing on offense," Bogut said. "I'd go inside and throw crap up there. I was 4-for-11 and the coaches at the half told me to take my time. In the second half I slowed myself down and I had more room to work." Colorado State frustrated Bogut early on, pushing and shoving him almost every time he crossed the lane. The big Australian shot just 4-of-11 and had three turnovers in the first half, though he still managed to get 11 points and seven rebounds. But the physical play only seemed to make Bogut mad. He let out a yell after forcing a turnover in the corner early in the second half and was even more forceful on offense, using a variety of up-and-unders, hooks and putbacks to help the Utes pull away. Bogut finished 10-of-21 and had eight offensive rebounds, using his edge in experience to take advantage of freshmen Stuart Creason and Jason Smith. "We had no answer for Bogut," Colorado State coach Dale Layer said. "He was a man playing with young men tonight. He imposed his will on the game." Utah (15-3, 3-0 Mountain West) struggled at both ends in a tight first half before pulling away early in the second by dominating at both ends. The Utes hit 10-of-16 shots and held Colorado State without a field goal for nearly eight minutes to turn a six-point deficit into a 55-39 lead with nine minutes left. Bryant Markson added 20 points and Tim Drisdom hit some big 3-pointers in the second half to finish with 14 points, giving Utah its longest winning streak since taking 13 straight in 2001-02. "The only things we can control is our defensive energy and getting up into people," Utah coach Ray Giacoletti said. "I guess we wanted to pace ourselves." Colorado State (9-7, 1-2) probably should have. The Rams shot 15-of-22 and gave Utah problems with their big lineup -- three 7-footers started -- in the first half before falling apart in the second. Colorado State made just 6 of 23 shots in the second half and wasn't any better defensively. The Rams were outrebounded 36-19, including 15-5 on the offensive glass, and allowed Utah to make 14 of 22 shots in the second half to see their 10-game home winning streak come to end. Matt Nelson was the only Colorado State player to finish in double figures, scoring 10 points on 5-of-9 shooting. "It was a tale of two halves," Layer said. "I thought in the second half they dominated in every phase of the game."

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.
